description: Manage applications running on an Azure Service Fabric cluster. Only support ARM deployed applications.

commands.name: az sf application create
commands.summary: Create a new application on an Azure Service Fabric cluster.
examples:
az sf application create -g testRG -c testCluster --application-name testApp --application-type-name TestAppType \
  --application-type-version v1 --application-parameters key0=value0

az sf application create -g testRG -c testCluster --application-name testApp --application-type-name TestAppType \
  --application-type-version v1 --package-url "https://sftestapp.blob.core.windows.net/sftestapp/testApp_1.0.sfpkg" \
    --application-parameters key0=value0

commands.name: az sf application delete
examples: az sf application delete -g testRG -c testCluster --application-name testApp

commands.name: az sf application list
commands.summary: List applications of a given cluster.
examples: az sf application list -g testRG -c testCluster

commands.name: az sf application show
commands.summary: Show the properties of an application on an Azure Service Fabric cluster.
examples: az sf application show -g testRG -c testCluster --application-name testApp

commands.name: az sf application update
commands.summary: Update a Azure Service Fabric application. This allows updating the application parameters and/or upgrade the application type version which will trigger an application upgrade.
commands.syntax:
az sf application update --application-name
                         --cluster-name
                         --resource-group
                         [--application-parameters]
                         [--application-type-version]
                         [--consider-warning-as-error {false, true}]
                         [--failure-action {Manual, Rollback}]
                         [--force-restart {false, true}]
                         [--hc-retry-timeout]
                         [--hc-stable-duration]
                         [--hc-wait-duration]
                         [--max-nodes]
                         [--max-porcent-unhealthy-apps]
                         [--max-porcent-unhealthy-partitions]
                         [--max-porcent-unhealthy-replicas]
                         [--max-porcent-unhealthy-services]
                         [--min-nodes]
                         [--rep-check-timeout]
                         [--service-type-health-policy-map]
                         [--ud-timeout]
                         [--upgrade-timeout]
examples:
az sf application update -g testRG -c testCluster --application-name testApp --application-type-version v2 \
  --application-parameters key0=value0 --health-check-stable-duration 0 --health-check-wait-duration 0 --health-check-retry-timeout 0 \
    --upgrade-domain-timeout 5000 --upgrade-timeout 7000 --failure-action Rollback --upgrade-replica-set-check-timeout 300 --force-restart
az sf application update -g testRG -c testCluster --application-name testApp --minimum-nodes 1 --maximum-nodes 3
